title: NLDS Game 2: Stephen Strasburg spectacular as Nationals even series with Dodgers
text:
CLOSE

LOS ANGELES — This just in: Washington Nationals ace Stephen Strasburg can pitch on short rest.

And the Nationals aren’t going to roll over for the Los Angeles Dodgers.

Despite throwing three innings Tuesday in the wild-card game, Strasburg turned in a stellar performance Friday as the Washington Nationals beat the Dodgers 4-2 in Game 2 of the National League Division Series.

Strasburg retired the first 14 batters he faced, allowed just one run in six innings and had 10 strikeouts as the Nationals evened the NLDS at 1-game apiece. The Nationals also gained homefield advantage as the best-of-5 series moves to Washington for Game 3 on Sunday and Game 4 on Monday.

The Dodgers threatened in the ninth inning with Daniel Hudson on the mound. He was able to strike out Corey Seager with the bases loaded to earn the save.

On Friday at Dodger Stadium, the Nationals took advantage of a shaky Clayton Kershaw, jumping out to a 3-0 after two innings. Then it was a matter of holding on as the Dodgers cut the deficit to 3-2 in the bottom of the seventh.

Stephen Strasburg held the Dodgers offense to one run. (Photo: Robert Hanashiro, USA TODAY Sports)

GOING TO THE MAX

Max Scherzer was scheduled to start Game 3 for the Nationals. Well, so much for that, so we think.

With the Nationals clinging to a 4-2 lead heading into the eighth inning, Nationals manager Davey Martinez brought in Scherzer. Wise move.

Scherzer retired the Dodgers in order in the eighth by striking out the side.

CLAYTON CURSE-SHAW?

Is it a postseason curse that unsettles Clayton Kershaw, the three-time Cy Young Award winner who entered game with a 4.32 ERA in 30 playoff appearances? Or just postseason anxiety? There was yet more reason to wonder after witnessing this:

During 178 1/3 innings pitched during the regular season, Kershaw hit just two batters. On Friday, he managed to equal that total in just two innings — plunking Juan Soto in the first and nailing Victor Robles in the second. It was part of more postseason misadventures for Kershaw, who allowed seven of the first 12 batters he faced to reach base.

Somehow Kershaw escaped those two shaky innings while allowing just three runs. More impressively, he retired nine of the next 10 batters and exited after six innings of semi-adequate postseason pitching.

LA's NEW ACE? Buehler validates he can handle the big stage

BREAKING IT UP

OK, maybe it’s a tad early to be tracking potential no-hitters with two outs in the fifth inning. So forgive us as we report .. Will Smith, the Dodgers’ rookie catcher, broke up Strasburg’s no-hit bid with two outs in the bottom of the fifth. For the record, there have been only two no-hitters in major league baseball's postseason history — Don Larsen’s perfect game for the Dodgers against the New York Yankees in Game 5 of the 1956 World Series and Roy Halladay’s no-hitter for the Philadelphia Phillies against the the Cincinnati Reds in Game 1 of the 2010 National League Division Series.

There seemed to be a glimmer of hope of a third postseason no-hitter when Strasburg struck out Cody Bellinger and Max Muncy for the first two outs of the fifth inning as the Dodgers’ offense looked lifeless. But then up stepped Smith, the baby-faced 24-year-old who laced a 2-2 change to center for a single that ended the no-hit bid.

MAY IN OCTOBER?

It was mildly surprising that rookie pitcher Dustin May made the Dodgers’ NL Division Series. On Friday, Dodgers manager Dave Roberts demonstrated he’s not afraid to use the redheaded reliever in significant situations — such as top of the seventh, bases loaded with two out and the Dodgers trailing 3-1.

How’d it work out? May threw five pitches to veteran Howie Kendrick before inducing Kendrick into a weak ground.
description: Nationals' Stephen Strasburg took a perfect game into the fifth inning against the Dodgers. Washington evened the NLDS series 1-1.
